segment.source: Map DirectX 9 features to DirectX 11 APIs
segment.target: Map DirectX 9 features to DirectX 11 APIs

segment.source: Understand how the features your Direct3D 9 game uses will translate to Direct3D 11 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: Understand how the features your Direct3D 9 game uses will translate to Direct3D 11 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: Map DirectX 9 features to DirectX 11 APIs
segment.target: Map DirectX 9 features to DirectX 11 APIs

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Important changes from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11
segment.target: Important changes from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11

segment.source: Understand how the features your Direct3D 9 game uses will translate to Direct3D 11 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: Understand how the features your Direct3D 9 game uses will translate to Direct3D 11 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: Direct3D is still the foundation of DirectX graphics, but the API has changed since DirectX 9:
segment.target: Direct3D is still the foundation of DirectX graphics, but the API has changed since DirectX 9:

segment.source: Microsoft DirectX Graphics Infrastructure (DXGI) is used to set up graphics adapters.
segment.target: Microsoft DirectX Graphics Infrastructure (DXGI) is used to set up graphics adapters.

segment.source: Use DXGI to select buffer formats, create swap chains, present frames, and create shared resources.
segment.target: Use DXGI to select buffer formats, create swap chains, present frames, and create shared resources.

segment.source: A Direct3D device context is used to set pipeline state and generate rendering commands.
segment.target: A Direct3D device context is used to set pipeline state and generate rendering commands.

segment.source: Most of our samples use an immediate context to render directly to the device; Direct3D 11 also supports multithreaded rendering, in which case deferred contexts are used.
segment.target: Most of our samples use an immediate context to render directly to the device; Direct3D 11 also supports multithreaded rendering, in which case deferred contexts are used.

segment.source: See Introduction to a Device in Direct3D 11.
segment.target: See Introduction to a Device in Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Some features have been deprecated, most notably the fixed function pipeline.
segment.target: Some features have been deprecated, most notably the fixed function pipeline.

segment.source: For a full list of Direct3D 11 features, see Direct3D 11 Features and Direct3D 11 Features.
segment.target: For a full list of Direct3D 11 features, see Direct3D 11 Features and Direct3D 11 Features.

segment.source: Direct2D (Windows) is still an important part of DirectX graphics and Windows.
segment.target: Direct2D (Windows) is still an important part of DirectX graphics and Windows.

segment.source: You can still use Direct2D to draw 2D games, and to draw overlays (HUDs) on top of Direct3D.
segment.target: You can still use Direct2D to draw 2D games, and to draw overlays (HUDs) on top of Direct3D.

segment.source: Direct2D runs on top of Direct3D; 2D games can be implemented using either API.
segment.target: Direct2D runs on top of Direct3D; 2D games can be implemented using either API.

segment.source: For example, a 2D game implemented using Direct3D can use orthographic projection, set Z-values to control the drawing order of primitives, and use pixel shaders to add special effects.
segment.target: For example, a 2D game implemented using Direct3D can use orthographic projection, set Z-values to control the drawing order of primitives, and use pixel shaders to add special effects.

segment.source: Since Direct2D is based on Direct3D it also uses DXGI and device contexts.
segment.target: Since Direct2D is based on Direct3D it also uses DXGI and device contexts.

segment.source: The DirectWrite API adds support for formatted text using Direct2D.
segment.target: The DirectWrite API adds support for formatted text using Direct2D.

segment.source: D3DX and DXUT are deprecated and cannot be used by UWP games.
segment.target: D3DX and DXUT are deprecated and cannot be used by UWP games.

segment.source: These helper libraries provided resources for tasks such as texture loading and mesh loading.
segment.target: These helper libraries provided resources for tasks such as texture loading and mesh loading.

segment.source: The Simple port from Direct3D 9 to UWP walkthrough demonstrates how to set up a window, initialize Direct3D, and do basic 3D rendering.
segment.target: The Simple port from Direct3D 9 to UWP walkthrough demonstrates how to set up a window, initialize Direct3D, and do basic 3D rendering.

segment.source: The Simple UWP game with DirectX walkthrough demonstrates common game programming tasks including graphics, loading files, UI, controls, and sound.
segment.target: The Simple UWP game with DirectX walkthrough demonstrates common game programming tasks including graphics, loading files, UI, controls, and sound.

segment.source: The DirectX Tool Kit community project offers helper classes for use with Direct3D 11 and UWP apps.
segment.target: The DirectX Tool Kit community project offers helper classes for use with Direct3D 11 and UWP apps.

segment.source: Move shader programs from FX to HLSL
segment.target: Move shader programs from FX to HLSL

segment.source: The D3DX utility library (D3DX 9, D3DX 10, and D3DX 11), including Effects, is deprecated for UWP.
segment.target: The D3DX utility library (D3DX 9, D3DX 10, and D3DX 11), including Effects, is deprecated for UWP.

segment.source: All DirectX games for UWP drive the graphics pipeline using HLSL without Effects.
segment.target: All DirectX games for UWP drive the graphics pipeline using HLSL without Effects.

segment.source: Visual Studio still uses FXC under the hood to compile shader objects.
segment.target: Visual Studio still uses FXC under the hood to compile shader objects.

segment.source: UWP game shaders are compiled ahead of time.
segment.target: UWP game shaders are compiled ahead of time.

segment.source: The bytecode is loaded at runtime, then each shader resource is bound to the graphics pipeline during the appropriate rendering pass.
segment.target: The bytecode is loaded at runtime, then each shader resource is bound to the graphics pipeline during the appropriate rendering pass.

segment.source: Shaders should be moved to their own separate .HLSL files and rendering techniques should be implemented in your C++ code.
segment.target: Shaders should be moved to their own separate .HLSL files and rendering techniques should be implemented in your C++ code.

segment.source: For a quick look at loading shader resources see Simple port from Direct3D 9 to UWP.
segment.target: For a quick look at loading shader resources see Simple port from Direct3D 9 to UWP.

segment.source: Direct3D 11 introduced Shader Model 5, which requires Direct3D feature level 110 (or above).
segment.target: Direct3D 11 introduced Shader Model 5, which requires Direct3D feature level 110 (or above).

segment.source: See HLSL Shader Model 5 Features for Direct3D 11.
segment.target: See HLSL Shader Model 5 Features for Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Code using XNAMath (or D3DXMath) should be migrated to DirectXMath.
segment.target: Code using XNAMath (or D3DXMath) should be migrated to DirectXMath.

segment.source: DirectXMath includes types that are portable across x86, x64, and ARM.
segment.target: DirectXMath includes types that are portable across x86, x64, and ARM.

segment.source: See Code Migration from the XNA Math Library.
segment.target: See Code Migration from the XNA Math Library.

segment.source: Note that DirectXMath float types are convenient for use with shaders.
segment.target: Note that DirectXMath float types are convenient for use with shaders.

segment.source: For example XMFLOAT4 and XMFLOAT4X4 conveniently align data for constant buffers.
segment.target: For example XMFLOAT4 and XMFLOAT4X4 conveniently align data for constant buffers.

segment.source: Replace DirectSound with XAudio2 (and background audio)
segment.target: Replace DirectSound with XAudio2 (and background audio)

segment.source: DirectSound is not supported for UWP:
segment.target: DirectSound is not supported for UWP:

segment.source: Use XAudio2 to add sound effects to your game.
segment.target: Use XAudio2 to add sound effects to your game.

segment.source: Replace DirectInput with XInput and UWP APIs
segment.target: Replace DirectInput with XInput and UWP APIs

segment.source: DirectInput is not supported for UWP:
segment.target: DirectInput is not supported for UWP:

segment.source: Use CoreWindow input event callbacks for mouse, keyboard, and touch input.
segment.target: Use CoreWindow input event callbacks for mouse, keyboard, and touch input.

segment.source: Use XInput 1.4 for game controller support (and game controller headset support).
segment.target: Use XInput 1.4 for game controller support (and game controller headset support).

segment.source: If you are using a shared code base for desktop and UWP, see XInput Versions for information on backwards compatibility.
segment.target: If you are using a shared code base for desktop and UWP, see XInput Versions for information on backwards compatibility.

segment.source: Register for EdgeGesture events if your game needs to use the app bar.
segment.target: Register for EdgeGesture events if your game needs to use the app bar.

segment.source: Use Microsoft Media Foundation instead of DirectShow
segment.target: Use Microsoft Media Foundation instead of DirectShow

segment.source: DirectShow is no longer part of the DirectX API (or the Windows API).
segment.target: DirectShow is no longer part of the DirectX API (or the Windows API).

segment.source: Microsoft Media Foundation provides video content to Direct3D using shared surfaces.
segment.target: Microsoft Media Foundation provides video content to Direct3D using shared surfaces.

segment.source: If your game uses network services, you need to provide networking code that complies with UWP requirements.
segment.target: If your game uses network services, you need to provide networking code that complies with UWP requirements.

segment.source: Win32 and COM for Windows Store apps (networking) (Windows)
segment.target: Win32 and COM for Windows Store apps (networking) (Windows)

segment.source: The following articles help you add networking features and declare support for networking in your app's package manifest.
segment.target: The following articles help you add networking features and declare support for networking in your app's package manifest.

segment.source: Connecting with sockets (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)
segment.target: Connecting with sockets (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)

segment.source: Connecting with WebSockets (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)
segment.target: Connecting with WebSockets (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)

segment.source: Connecting to web services (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)
segment.target: Connecting to web services (Windows Store apps using C#/VB/C++ and XAML) (Windows)

segment.source: Note that all UWP apps (including games) use specific types of background tasks to maintain connectivity while the app is suspended.
segment.target: Note that all UWP apps (including games) use specific types of background tasks to maintain connectivity while the app is suspended.

segment.source: If your game needs to maintain connection state while suspended see Networking basics.
segment.target: If your game needs to maintain connection state while suspended see Networking basics.

segment.source: Use the following table to help convert code from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11.
segment.target: Use the following table to help convert code from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11.

segment.source: This can also help distinguish between the device and device context.
segment.target: This can also help distinguish between the device and device context.

segment.source: The graphics pipeline stages are described in Graphics Pipeline.
segment.target: The graphics pipeline stages are described in Graphics Pipeline.

segment.source: Call [IDXGISwapChain1::Present1](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh446797) with the DXGI_PRESENT_TEST flag set.
segment.target: Call [IDXGISwapChain1::Present1](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh446797) with the DXGI_PRESENT_TEST flag set.

segment.source: LOST device and POOL_MANAGED no longer exist.
segment.target: LOST device and POOL_MANAGED no longer exist.

segment.source: [IDXGISwapChain1::Present1](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh446797) can fail with a [DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_REMOVED](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb509553) return value.
segment.target: [IDXGISwapChain1::Present1](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh446797) can fail with a [DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_REMOVED](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb509553) return value.

segment.source: The fixed-function pipeline has been deprecated.
segment.target: The fixed-function pipeline has been deprecated.

segment.source: Capability bits are replaced with feature levels.
segment.target: Capability bits are replaced with feature levels.

segment.source: Only a few format and feature usage cases are optional for any given feature level.
segment.target: Only a few format and feature usage cases are optional for any given feature level.

segment.source: These can be checked with [ID3D11Device::CheckFeatureSupport](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ff476497) and [ID3D11Device::CheckFormatSupport](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb173536).
segment.target: These can be checked with [ID3D11Device::CheckFeatureSupport](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ff476497) and [ID3D11Device::CheckFormatSupport](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb173536).

segment.source: Use the following table to convert Direct3D 9 formats into DXGI formats.
segment.target: Use the following table to convert Direct3D 9 formats into DXGI formats.

segment.source: Note Use .r swizzle in shader to duplicate red to other components to get Direct3D 9 behavior.
segment.target: Note Use .r swizzle in shader to duplicate red to other components to get Direct3D 9 behavior.

segment.source: Note Use swizzle .rrrg in shader to duplicate red and move green to the alpha components to get Direct3D 9 behavior.
segment.target: Note Use swizzle .rrrg in shader to duplicate red and move green to the alpha components to get Direct3D 9 behavior.

segment.source: Note In Direct3D 9 the data was scaled up by 255.0f, but this can be handled in the shader.
segment.target: Note In Direct3D 9 the data was scaled up by 255.0f, but this can be handled in the shader.

segment.source: Note In Direct3D 9 the data was scaled up by 255.0f, but this can be handled in the shader.
segment.target: Note In Direct3D 9 the data was scaled up by 255.0f, but this can be handled in the shader.

segment.source: Note DXT1 and DXT2 are the same from an API/hardware perspective.
segment.target: Note DXT1 and DXT2 are the same from an API/hardware perspective.

segment.source: The only difference is whether premultiplied alpha is used, which can be tracked by an application and doesn't need a separate format.
segment.target: The only difference is whether premultiplied alpha is used, which can be tracked by an application and doesn't need a separate format.

segment.source: Note DXT3 and DXT4 are the same from an API/hardware perspective.
segment.target: Note DXT3 and DXT4 are the same from an API/hardware perspective.

segment.source: The only difference is whether premultiplied alpha is used, which can be tracked by an application and doesn't need a separate format.
segment.target: The only difference is whether premultiplied alpha is used, which can be tracked by an application and doesn't need a separate format.

segment.source: Note Use .r swizzle in shader to duplicate red to other components to get D3D9 behavior.
segment.target: Note Use .r swizzle in shader to duplicate red to other components to get D3D9 behavior.

segment.source: Note The shader gets UINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed (0.0f, 1.0f... 255.f), UINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.
segment.target: Note The shader gets UINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed (0.0f, 1.0f... 255.f), UINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.

segment.source: Note The shader gets SINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed, SINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.
segment.target: Note The shader gets SINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed, SINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.

segment.source: Note The shader gets SINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed, SINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.
segment.target: Note The shader gets SINT values, but if Direct3D 9 style integral floats are needed, SINT can just be converted to float32 in the shader.

segment.source: Note Requires Feature Level 10.0 or later
segment.target: Note Requires Feature Level 10.0 or later

segment.source: Note Requires Feature Level 10.0 or later
segment.target: Note Requires Feature Level 10.0 or later
